situation: My son has been awake on his phone until 3 AM every night this week.
golden:
A) Tone check: This might bring up worry and a desire to protect sleep and wellbeing.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: rest + safety. Teen need: autonomy + stress relief or connection.
C) De-escalated message to send: "Hey, I’ve noticed you’ve been up really late on your phone this week. I’m feeling a bit worried because sleep affects your health and energy. I’d like us to figure out what’s keeping you up and make a plan that helps you get more rest. Can we talk about it?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "Is something making it hard to fall asleep lately?"

situation: My daughter starts gaming right after school and homework isn’t getting done.
golden:
A) Tone check: This can feel stressful and create a need for structure without sounding controlling.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: responsibility + progress. Teen need: downtime + autonomy.
C) De-escalated message to send: "I’ve noticed gaming often starts right after school, and homework seems to be getting squeezed out. I’m concerned because I want you to feel supported and stay on track. Could we set up a routine together—homework first, then a clear gaming window afterward?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "What would feel like a fair gaming window after school?"

situation: My teen stays in their room most evenings and rarely talks to us.
golden:
A) Tone check: This might bring up sadness and a desire for connection, and a gentle invitation may help.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: connection + reassurance. Teen need: space + emotional safety.
C) De-escalated message to send: "I’ve noticed we haven’t connected much lately, and I miss you. I care about how you’re doing and I’d like to understand what things have been like for you. Would you be open to a short check-in this week—however feels easiest for you?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "Would talking, texting, or doing something together feel easiest right now?"

situation: My son is on his phone during dinner and barely responds when we talk to him.
golden:
A) Tone check: This can feel frustrating and make you want connection.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: connection + presence. Teen need: autonomy + social connection.
C) De-escalated message to send: "I’ve noticed phones are often at the table, and I’m missing our time together. I really value dinner as a chance to connect. Would you be open to trying phone-free dinners a few nights this week so we can catch up?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "What would make phone-free dinners easier for you?"

situation: My daughter gets very angry when I ask her to stop scrolling at night.
golden:
A) Tone check: Nights can be sensitive; aim for calm and collaboration.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: sleep + calm. Teen need: autonomy + winding down.
C) De-escalated message to send: "I’ve noticed late-night scrolling has been turning into arguments, and I don’t want us to fight. I’m concerned about sleep and I’d like us to find a plan that feels fair. Can we talk about what makes it hard to stop at night and agree on a simple bedtime routine together?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "What helps you feel ready to put the phone down—music, a timer, or something else?"

situation: My son gets defensive when I ask who he is talking to online.
golden:
A) Tone check: Aim for calm curiosity and collaboration.
B) Needs guess: Parent need: trust + structure. Teen need: autonomy + respect.
C) De-escalated message to send: "I’ve noticed this situation lately, and I’m feeling concerned because I want things to go smoothly at home while also respecting your independence. I’d like us to talk about what’s going on and agree on a plan that feels fair to both of us. Would you be open to a quick conversation?"
D) One optional follow-up question: "What’s the most important thing you want me to understand about your perspective?"
